intro: Pulsatilla propera, commonly known as the pasque flower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, showy yellow to orange flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant has a short, thick stem with palmately divided leaves that are covered in a dense layer of fine hairs. Its flowers are typically surrounded by a crown of white or pale yellow sepals, and it produces small, hairy fruits that contain numerous seeds. Pulsatilla propera is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes, where it thrives in well-drained, sunny conditions.
